evidence: Each proton carries a magnetic moment
these moments precess around the external magnetic field
aligned parallel to the magnetic field
slightly more occupy the lower-energy state
We can treat it as a classical vector that can tilt, rotate, or precess
So, magnetization is the bridge from the microscopic quantum world of spins to the macroscopic signals we use in MRI

triples.evidence: This is what we call the net magnetization vector, often denoted as M.
triples.o: net vector pointing along the direction of the magnetic field

triples.evidence: Because the magnetic moments are vectors, those that are opposite to each other will cancel out in the transverse plane.
So, magnetization is the bridge from the microscopic quantum world of spins to the macroscopic signals we use in MRI.
The vector sum of all of the magnetic moments only has a z (longitudinal) component, with no component in the xy (transverse) plane.

concepts.term: when we add up all of their contributions, we obtain a single net vector pointing along the direction of the magnetic field

evidence: The vector sum of all of the magnetic moments only has a z (longitudinal) component, with no component in the xy (transverse) plane.
Each proton carries a magnetic moment, and as we have discussed, these moments precess around the external magnetic field.
In the population of protons, slightly more occupy the lower-energy state, aligned parallel to the magnetic field, while slightly fewer are in the higher-energy, anti-parallel state.
This imbalance, even though very small, is crucial.
So, magnetization is the bridge from the microscopic quantum world of spins to the macroscopic signals we use in MRI.
